column1: Term	Definition	Synonym	Mathematical or not	Quantifiable	Synonym	Synonym	Synonym	Synonym	Synonym	Synonym,,,
Catastrophic bifurcation	big' jump to an alternate attractor due to initial attractor									,,,
Domain of attraction	the range of values around which a system fluctuates				zone of fluctuation	basin of attraction	attractor	stable point		,,,
Regime shift	"""abrupt"" and ""persistent"" change in a system's structure or functioning"									,,,
Persistent	A relative value of the longevity of the observed change in values				long-lasting					,,,

Abrupt	A relative value of the speed and/or intensity of the change; the time period over which the regime shift occurs relative to the time observed (or expected to have been) in a particular state				big	fast	quick	large		,,,
Tipping point	A point in a system's trajectory where a small change in an endogenous force induces a large change in sytem state or values		mathematical							,,,
Exogeneous process (forcing, driver)	An external process influencing the state of the dynamical system									,,,
Dynamical system	A time-dependent system which can be described in state-space									,,,
Regime	"A set of system values that, while may revolved around a domain of attraction," is not necessarily stable nor stationary""
column11: The path of an object or system through space-time
column21: A system with statistical properties unchanging over time. This concept extends to periodic stationarity for systems exhibiting periodic behavior"," where the system may be non-stationary across periods but stationary within periods.""
column31: The study of complex systems theory; the study of time-dependent systems
column41: The study of abrupt changes within a dynamical system
column61: The study of measures and measurement (e.g.", volume, mass," time).""
column71: occurs when a stable point collides with an unstable point; when crossing a tipping point induces hysteresis
column81: When the recovery rate (time to return) of a system decreases as a system approaches a critical point (possibly a threshold or tipping point). A characteristic observed in some empirical systems data (e.g. nutrient loading in shallow lakes).
column91: The parameter values for a system that causes the system to shift between alternate attractors.
column101: The set of values towards which a system tends"," regardless of initial values ""
column111: An attractor which has fractal structure (an observable fractal dimension).
column121: The set of values around which a system revolves and does not change
column131: An equilibrium is stable when small perturbations do not induce change
column141: An equilibrium is unstable when small perturbations induce change.
column151: A system with extreme sensitivity to initial conditions.
column161: A graphical representation of two or more trajectories where one axis is not time. In this representation"," an equilibrium is represented as a single point.""
column181: A value that conveys the average rate of trajectory divergence that is caused by an endogenous force; how quickly (if at all) a system will tend away from a stable point if it starts near the stable point.
column191: A measurement of geometrical self-similarity; when a system has similar structure regardless of the scale of observation
column201: A system satisfied by  power-law scaling
column211: A system which is state-dependent (e.g. magnets); when a tipping point or threshold is crossed such that the previous state cannot be achieved by reversing the conditions.
